Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative research: Integrated studies of early stages of continental extension: From incipient (Okavango) to young (Malawi) rifts
Award.AbstractNarration:
Our current understanding of continental rifting is largely based on studies of evolved and relict rift systems. Observations from these studies have motivated and constrained numerical models that describe rift evolution from initiation to rupture. However, there are very few field observations that constrain processes occurring at the earliest stages of rifting and the structural controls on these processes. This project involves a project to investigate the question of what happens in the early stages of continental rifting. The East African Rift System (EARS), because of its proximity to the pole of rotation, exhibits a strong gradient in rift evolution along its length. This provides a unique opportunity to investigate the processes that drive rift initiation and control early rift localization.

The PIs will undertake a multidisciplinary investigation of the southwest branch of the EARS, which includes the very early stage Okavango Rift Zone, where classic geomorphic rift features are just beginning to emerge, and the Mweru, Luangwa (Zambia) and Malawi Rifts, where geomorphic features are fully developed but magma (if present) has yet to breach the surface. The PIs will apply a combination of geophysical, geological, geochemical and geodynamic techniques across the southwest branch of the EARS to test the predictions of those hypotheses. Passive seismic data will constrain lithospheric-scale structure and upper-mantle flow patterns. Wide angle seismic profiling, along with gravity data, will constrain variations in crustal and uppermost mantle structure. Magnetotelluric measurements will provide system-scale constraints on lithospheric thin spots and the presence of melt, while remote sensing and field mapping will be used to map surface deformation. Geochemical analysis of hot spring fluids will identify the presence of mantle-derived melts. Geodynamic modeling will synthesize the new geophysical observations and geochemical results to develop the next generation of continental rifting models.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Models developed to explain how rifts form represent a spectrum between two end members described as “Active” or “Passive” rifting. In active rifting, lithospheric extension is enhanced by the presence of magmas derived from a hot upwelling asthenosphere. Magma softens the lithosphere, enhancing rifting. In passive rifting, lithospheric extension is the result of far field forces generated by plate motions. Indeed, due to the amount of force required and available it is next to impossible to rupture the lithosphere by only mechanical stretching of the lithosphere. This poses a significant challenge in our understanding of rift initiation because there are numerous examples of rift systems worldwide where rifting is not accompanied by magmatism (e.g., The magma poor Western Branch of the East African Rift System) questioning the necessity for magma as a requirement for rifting. To date, most research on rift systems have targeted magma (rich) assisted rifts. Almost no research has focused on understanding the processes that initiate and control the earliest stages of magma poor rifts. Our study addressed this knowledge gap by targeting several magma poor rifts. Our objectives were to: (1) constrain the upper mantle and crustal structure beneath rifts, (2) use the chemistry of hot springs as a “sniffer” of near surface magmatic activity, and (3) conduct geomorphologic and kinematic studies to understand fault evolution during rifting. We targeted the Okavango Rift Zone, Botswana (where extension has barely commenced and classic geomorphic rift features are absent) and the Malawi, Albertine-Rhino (Uganda) and Luangwa (Zambia) rifts where although exhibiting fully developed geomorphic rift characteristics, surface magmatism if present has yet to reach the surface.

Our results from the Okavango suggest that the crust is 4-5 km thinner beneath the rift, is characterized by elevated heat flow, and that an altered mantle lies beneath the rift. We propose that upward migration of hot mantle fluids that utilized Precambrian lithospheric structures as conduits may be responsible for weakening the lithosphere leading to rifting.

Beneath the Luangwa rift valley, we found no elevated heat flow, a heterogeneous thick crust and the presence of an under-plated mafic body beneath the rift. This deep magmatic activity introduced rheological weaknesses enhancing strain localization but never breached the surface.

We found no systematic pattern of crustal thinning and elevated heat flow beneath the axis of the Malawi Rift. Instead, we observed a thinner lithosphere beneath the rift suggesting that most of the strain during the extension of the Malawi Rift is preferentially localized in the sub-continental lithospheric mantle.

Finally, we found that elevated heat flow underlies the southern part of the Albertine rift. This thermal anomaly exhibits a strong northward attenuation.  Additionally, there is no consistent crustal thinning beneath the entire axis of the Albertine-Rhino rift. Instead the thinned crust lies beneath the western escarpment.  We suggest the thermal anomaly beneath the rift is due to hot fluids sourced from the Toro Ankole volcanic fields in the south utilizing Precambrian shear zones as conduits.

Taken together, we found no convincing evidence for the presence of shallow magma bodies. This observation is supported by the geochemistry data of hot springs that show little evidence for a mantle contribution except at one location in northern L. Malawi.  We infer that the variability in crustal thickness beneath the rifts is probably inherited from the older (pre-rift) lithospheric accreted terranes. We therefore advocate for a three end-member model that incorporates pre-rift lithospheric heterogeneity and tectonic history (Figure 1).

Our activities contributed to the building of the infrastructure necessary to facilitate future U.S. collaborations in sub-Saharan Africa. Our students were instrumental in providing peer instruction to their African peers thereby helping to build capacity in our partner African countries (Figure 2). At the same time our activities strengthened early career faculty and student research skills and built international experience and network skills that students need to effectively function in an increasingly globalized environment. A total of 14 students (1 PhD, 8 MS and 5 BS) participated in the project. We built new international academic partnerships in Malawi, Zambia and Botswana, provided international research field experience for students, promoted global engagement of U.S. scientific workforce in sub-Saharan Africa. We engaged 5 minority and 5 female students, thereby enhancing diversity in STEM fields. The results of this study were presented at several venues including seminars at various universities across the nation and at national and international meetings. We published 27 abstracts, 4 manuscripts and we have several more in preparation.  Africa is slated to become a game changer in oil and gas exploration and the East African Rift System is central to new discoveries. Our study will provide scientific input into the use of magnetic techniques for heat flow estimation critical for determining basin sediment maturity for oil and gas exploration and for geothermal exploration.
